[Story]: # The Funeral


The dry eaves blew along the autumn wind

Singing the ocean's song to the ears in the land locked hollow.

The tops of the hills shaded the lane occasionally giving way to glimpses of a sunset as the funeral procession poured toward the family plot nestled in the back of the homestead between two limestone cliffs.

Duke was waiting with his fathers casket. The preacher stood, casting a shadow over the 6 foot hole that would soon hold the memories of the old man's bones. The preacher's wife stood by duke knowing that words could not penetrate the spell of grief that silenced the young man. Nor could her own losses teach her anything about his future.

Duke stood. Though his eyes were gazing down the lane, he was nowhere to be found in them.

In the blackness of his mind stood a rocky bluff, beaten by waves

"We're free, but we're in hell," whispered a thought.

The procession gathered in the borrowed church chairs. The indiscrete tones filled the hollow as each person clung to the edges of their mind. Not wanting to consider the haunting vision of their future. The loss was enough, though nobody knew the deceases past his steadfast oars through which he steered the generational family, donations to the church, and sparse involvement in town events. Time was this man's god, and other people were it's cost.

Next to the open grave lay Duke's mother. Her headstone was clean and polished like the love that she brought Duke's heart. She was seen and known for her sacrifices to her husband and to her hands. The world had swallowed her 3 years prior. Decades too early for Duke.

Duke took his seat and the preacher's wife next to him. The preacher stood with his head bowed over the casket mumbling to himself while he slowly turned to face the congregation.

"Today we honor a man

Who lived his life to the letter of the law, who gave his blood to his farm, his friends, and his kin. He walked among us like an omen

He stood Collected, Kind and Disciplined.

A teacher in the spirit of nature"

The preacher opened his bible to the gospel of John and spoke a sermon about light and the old man's life. He spoke about the passage of death. That it was indefinite and celebratory. That it was indeed both an end and a beginning.

The preacher did not care for any of his words. He had stopped caring years before when the world started to change and the mirror that greeted him every morning stopped staring so kindly. His words had no answers in them anymore. They were merely shorelines for his people and he was the one tasked with saying them.

Everybody was there for Duke, not for his father whose mountainous behavior left him isolated. The old man was a remnant of a fire that was dying out taking with it the emptiness of living for oneself.

The preacher's words came to a close. The sun was setting behind a cloud shrouding the grove in dark blue shadows. Duke stood from his chair and shook the preachers hand, thanking him in a rasped panicked voice. He touched the casket and placed his father's hat on it.

Not knowing what to do next, he awkwardly turned around and eyed the preacher and his wife.

Turning his back, he knocked on the casket and whispered

"Bye dad"

Falling out of him like a breath.

He could hear the preacher's wife directing the seated audience- a reception at the house. Duke could feel hands patting his back in comfort and murmurs of condolences. Filling in the space around him. Squeezing his chest.

The eruption of people broke the levee that Duke had created, forcing him to look up.

"I need you all to go on ahead," bellowing as his knees shook but he wouldn't budge. Just pressed his hands harder and harder onto the casket,

"Back to the house ya'll, I'll meet you there."

The preacher and his wife began corralling the procession toward the lane, as the townsfolk retrieved their chairs and loaded them into the pickup truck.

The preacher's sons had been standing at the edge of the clearing leaning on their shovels, next to the pickup truck that had brought the casket out. They stood like crows, above it and unindoctrinated in grief. Only waiting for their father's voice to command them to the task of lowering and burying Duke's father.

Duke could feel a heat rapture his face as he fought back tears and a place somewhere in his lungs began to tremor begging for breath. The air was a cool liquid that he felt behind his chest and this breath had carried every other breath in his lungs. His face was enveloped in heat as his salt stung his eyes. He wiped them as he turned - nodding toward the waiting preacher and walked toward the shovel to bury his father.

# The Drought

There was no rain that summer but Duke's farm had remained operational. The local reservoir had not completely run dry but it would not last as there had been many summers like this over the preceding decades. Pressed, the local farmers traded in their families heirloom properties for mansions, allowing the chain of progress to fill in behind them. What had once been thousands of acres of orchards, golden fields of wheat and corn, waves of furrows of green alfalfa, lay giant boxes placed end to end – homes for everybody from the nearby city and for all people pulled by the gravity of lower real estate costs and new lives in this suburb.

The county was becoming *that* despite the proximity to the largest city nearby being more than an hours drive. Though this once village had no association to that city, it was becoming a pre-fix to be never spoken of in its own history.

Duke knew this. His father had begun witnessing it before his death several years prior. They had watched as nearby communities became absorbed by the looming monolith to industry. There were new stores and new people. The dusty shadows that had camouflaged the townsfolk had become tapestried with new shades of colors each more vibrant than the last.

The old timers hated this emergence. They would hold court at local diners and glare at every visitor that would pass through their doors.

Standoffish men became bitter

Bitter men became silent.

Duke was not among either – though his father had become the silent type. Duke had no reason for lament- the community was changing in proportion to his curiosity. At times, he thought it was his young age, but he was not much younger than most bitter ranchers left. This farm had been the anchor of his family's heart for 4 generations. The trees and rocks had become the song that his life breathed through. The farm was the only hearth that he had known. Playing in it as a respite, then ultimately knowing it as his own personal clock.

This year, the ground was dustier and dying. He pulled only 3 out of 5 cuttings. 1 less then the year prior. There would be no profit this year. The few cattle that he ran could not diminish like his crops but no profit meant no feed and seed. No feed and seed meant that his farm might take the inevitable passage that had pulled his cohorts.

-----

The August sun bore down on Duke's shoulders as he walked the lane to the family cemetery. The leaves from the bordering trees gave his skin intermittent relief and a quiet breeze dried his sweat. The cottonwoods swallowed Duke's eyes and the old knots and hallowed trunks warmed his chest with the feeling that a part of him was cocooned in their bark.

He fumbled in his pocket for the handkerchief to wipe his brow. He arrived at the family plot to see first his fathers grave, covered in grass and prairie flower. Adjacent his mothers tombstone lay prominently marking his loss 6 years prior. They were both from this county, though his mother was an only child and her family's line had come to a close with her. He never imagined their bodies to mingle in decay. They were separate and distinct from each other in their marriage and would be apart even through death, until the earth claimed their coffins too.

There were 4 generations of men, women, and some children in this cemetery. The bones of Duke's family stretched across the historical divide from homesteader to rancher. Though parcels had been sold off over the century, this land had seen the Great Depression and the advent of million dollar tractors. Duke wasn't sentimental but the farm was the only thing he knew. The cold cement echoed against his face as his cheeks tingled underneath his beard.

"Dad, I don't know if this land is gunna make it. The water's gone, the sun's got hotter, the feed's doubled in price and there's no sign of it lettin' up. I know you said stick with it. That this farm is bigger than me or you. But I think God's got other plans. Buck next door is selling. He's got a nice price for it. Nothing like the offers that you got. The dirt's dust. I don't see it getting wetter. I don't feel the end.

I know what your gunna say, 'don't let the city get you. Don't be swallowed by the swarm.

But you know, it's only a matter of time with no rain.

Momma, I know you never much cared for this place. I know you'd itch to leave as soon as a door opened."

The sun was soft but still warm. The clouds were dispersing in the distance and the grove held nothing but silence. Duke could hear his own searching. He felt embarrassed that he even had to ask. Duke felt like he was performing. Somehow he believed that he was supposed to already know the answer. Already know how to navigate this changing tide. He knew there was no one there to answer and the emptiness that his words fell against made him feel like a fool.

With frustration, he turned around and started marching his way back to the house. What answers had his father? He was dead. What good were his bones but a memory of his forms inevitable end? The hubris of his father to think that he could out last the great machine. His own hubris for even considering that he was an exception to the rule.

Capable of selling or not, this land had shaped him and his very mind. He did not know himself apart from it. Every fiber of his being resisted the claim to be separate from the land. To be an individual pressing into the monolithic new age and bouncing off the new curiosities that modern industry had to offer. Duke knew that he was at a threshold and there was no exit that his heart could conjure to depart from his ever growing anguish – there was only suffocation.

The sun was beginning to set as Duke made it to the porch steps. There was nothing waiting for him inside except a few beers and a roast he cooked the night before. Wandering around his yard, he picked up the loose pieces of trash that had blown in from other parts of the property. Bringing the refuse to his garbage can, he went inside knowing there was no way to ease his consternation. There was no way out of his binding blade.

# The Echo

Duke drained the rocks of their energy. The land no longer harnessed the power of the soul. The fields became barren and void. The cows mingled slower to the troughs and the limits of Duke's hopes shown unearthed. The trees lived like they always had, bordering the homestead. The green that used to illuminate the center of the farm transformed itself into a papyrus brown as life from that spring that had fed the land so generously emptied without replenishment – the rocks drying out.

Light pressed through the blinds into Dukes room. The pools of dust whirled in the rays of sunlight at the foot of his bed. Duke stared, absorbed in its clou,d watching the space between the dust. Watching currents move while the light remained stationary. He was already late to feed the cattle, but they had become accustomed to a daylit breakfast, adjusting for their caretakers evening habits.

Staggering out of bed he found his irrigation boots and made his way to the barn to load his ATV with hay. The hungry herd was waiting, singing to each other in their semicircle. Duke broke apart the bale and splayed the flakes for the beasts. His head was booming and swirling as his stomach felt like it was sucked into his spine. His hands were tremoring as he took off his gloves – he reminded himself that he only needed to keep them alive until the next season. Grabbing the truck keys, he trudged to the drive-way and hopped into his silver truck.

Nobody was on the road this Sunday morning. They were either in church or away- looking to rediscover their foothold in nature. Nobody was there to witness Duke wrestle with the strongest motivation to pull his car into each passing power pole, every ditch, every large boulder. It would take nothing but a swift jerk of the wheel to the left or the right, to find a home in the immediate compression as his truck flung him to his timely death. He had watched it happen over and over in his head. This was his landscape to his journey townward. This was the road that Duke feared every time he stepped into that truck since his father's passing. He could feel the water in him asking for a way out but every day he kept driving, his hands becoming tighter and tighter against the steering wheel as the weeks turned into months, his hands becoming tighter as his negotiation set deeper into his jaw, then into his chest, then to his lungs where a small pocket of air carried the rest of him.

Duke passed the city limits sign slowing his resolve while he anticipated the path to his gas station. The lot was empty but for the owner's car. He parked his truck and walked in through the glass door; nodding at the man behind the counter reading his newspaper. These two needed no words, the owner had known Duke since he had purchased the timeless store. Duke grabbed his 12 pack from the cooler, a sandwich from the heater, a pack of gum, cup of coffee, and walked up to the register.

"Now you know its dry today, I tell you every Sunday. The law don't let me sell on Sundays. You want your beer, drive the 20 minutes to the next county"

Duke stood blankly, though the sleep was out of his eyes, he still felt the weight of it holding down his eyelids.

"You know days don't work like that out here"

The shopkeeper said nothing

Duke shrugged

Putting the daily provisions down he walked up to the register. He tossed his sandwich on the counter. I'll take 50 on pump 2

The shopkeeper nodded

"You want your tickets?"

Duke Shook his head

He walked out making his way to the bed of his truck. Sitting and drinking his morning cup while his tank fueled.

A green crossover rolled into the station's parking lot filled with a family. 2 little brown boys, a girl, and their parents. Duke eyed them inquisitively – there had been new people coming into town for the last couple of decades but this family pulled his attention. Their presence forced air down his chest and a small tremor sang from a space behind his ribs. Duke could feel his bones for the first time since his father died. They quivered and ached against the bed of his truck.

He watched as the family filed out of the car- the father exhausted but smiling, the mother resting in her own enchantment, like she had won herself over. The children reminded him of his school days. One was quietly watching while the other two played a slapping game as the family swirled into the gas station. The parents waved and Duke returned the gesture with barely enough time for them to see before they approached the door.

Duke's tank finished fueling

He took a sip of coffee and slipped off the back of his truck.

------

He drove homeward meandering from back road to back road, not knowing who was driving. He found the road to the highway that led south to the nearest county. In the years preceding, there were no events that marked his days nor an inner will to admit that he had lost contact with his sense of time. The highway took him 10 minutes to the adjacent county that wasn't dry on Sundays. Pulling into the first gas station, he sat in the moment between the truck halting and the release of his key in the ignition – his lips pursed and his fingers tapping the steering wheel. Traffic had picked up picked up carrying church goes home creating a wall of noise. Duke was met with a lull in the flow revealing the sounds of shifting metal creak in his ears while his truck settled.

A glint in his eye and a glimmer of a sneer marked his descent from the truck. Duke marched through the gas station door. Entranced as he opened the door, he made his way to the gas cans on the bottom shelf. Grabbing 4, he waltzed to the counter.

# The Passage

*Bottled Tempests*

*Scorching the summers weave*

*Ashes to Ashes*

*Dust to Dust*

Dukes blood pulsed with each step. With each step his face became tighter and tighter. He shut the curtains in his parents bedroom, preserved as it had been since nobody slept there these days. The dust didn't bother him, but this day he could see just how much had gathered on the linens. His boots echoed across the wood floors as he went from window to window, yanking the cloth shut. Grabbing one of the gas cans, he flung the petrol across the mattress that his parents had rested their limbs on for decades.

He tipped the container over at the doorway and watched the puddle spread between the floor boards. Duke barreled to the guest room and did the same thing. He spied the pictures on the wall that were a testament to his mother's interior decorating. Taking them off the wall and tossing them on the floor he emptied the second container over the glass and wood.

He trudged to his room and flipped his bed over . The mattress slammed into the window sending shards of glass to the backyard, 2 stories below. He cleared the clothes out of the closet and dumped them on the bed. Dukes hands started to shake as he emptied the third container. The fumes burned the inside of his nose.

The smell was not transitive, it neither carried him to any memory nor even attracted his attention at all. In truth, Duke was intoxicated by the fumes and drank them in, feeling the touch and timbre in his throat.

He finished dousing the third room and set out to finish the rest of the house. At this point the bottoms of his boots were wet and the floor had become slick. He leaped down the stairs with the fourth and last container of fuel. Drenching the front room of his family's farmhouse. The shadows from the already closed curtains danced around the center of the room. His home was unrecognizable. The couches that he had slept on sat motionless and stale. There was no one there. There was nothing left living in that old home.

Duke took the final container and removed the cap. He timidly made his way to the front door that he had entered and exited thousands of times. His boots getting wetter and wetter. The door warred with him. His eyes became absorbed in the seams of the wood. The knots and rings pulling him into them. The brass hinges, made by his great grandfather, reflected the sepia light in the room. He felt his face getting tighter and tighter and pressure in his lips became unbearable as he reached forward.

-----

The door flew open as he fell to his feet

The earth took his wound and he gave it his life.

He walked onto the dirt in front of him

Letting the light fall on his face and the air became pregnant fire.

The earth bore it and moved him to his car

He stepped into the cab and drove away."

# The Fading Light

Duke's heart pounded against the steering wheel of his truck,  each beat a question,  each question a plea to be answered.  The road ahead,  stretching into nothingness,  was the only path he knew.  But today,  it felt different.  The familiar landscape blurred,  a testament to the blurred lines of his own existence.

As he drove,  the realization settled heavy in his chest—his life,  once rooted in the land,  was now adrift,  sailing aimlessly towards an unknown horizon.  The farm,  his father's legacy,  was dying a slow death,  much like his father had after the drought claimed his land.  And with the farm,  Duke felt his own life force ebbing away,  a gradual extinguishing of the light that once burned bright within him.

The gas station where he'd stopped was like a mirage,  a beacon of normalcy in a world that seemed to have tilted on its axis.  Inside,  the familiar faces greeted him with the same smiles,  the same nods,  the same routine.  But Duke was no longer the same man.

As he drove away,  the small family in the green crossover became a symbol of everything he yearned for yet feared.  Change was coming,  invisible forces reshaping the world around him,  and Duke felt powerless to stop it.

Back at the farm,  the silence was deafening.  The house,  once a cocoon of childhood memories,  now felt like a tomb.  Duke's actions,  so deliberate,  so final,  seemed to echo through the empty rooms,  a haunting reminder of the life he was leaving behind.

The gasoline,  poured with such meticulous care,  was a tangible representation of his grief,  his anger,  his despair.  Each can,  emptied onto the mattresses,  the pictures,  the floors,  was a step further into the abyss.  Yet,  as he stood in the doorway,  the cap in his hand,  Duke felt a strange sense of calm.

He had come to the crossroads,  a place where his past and his future collided.  The farm,  the family,  the legacy—it was all slipping through his fingers,  like sand.  And in that moment of clarity,  Duke understood that he couldn't bring himself to destroy the house.  The farmhouse,  for all its memories,  was more than just a structure.  It was a symbol of resilience,  of perseverance,  of the unbreakable bond between generations.

With a heavy heart,  Duke walked back into the house,  cans in hand.  He poured the gasoline into the cans,  restored them to the shelf,  and locked the door behind him.

The drive back to the gas station was a journey through reflection.  The weight of his decisions,  the gravity of his actions,  pressed down on him,  a constant reminder of the precipice he had stood upon.

As he reached the gas station,  the family in the crossover was gone,  leaving behind an empty space where they had parked.  Duke walked inside,  the bell above the door jingling in greeting.

"Another day, " the shopkeeper said,  nodding,  his eyes catching the newspaper headline: "Drought Crisis Deepens,  Farmers Seek New Beginnings."

Duke nodded back,  his mind far away.  He paid for his fuel,  picked up his beer,  and sandwich,  and walked back to his truck.

The drive home was quiet.  The sun was setting,  painting the sky in hues of orange and pink,  a stark contrast to the dark clouds that had been his constant companions.  Duke felt a flicker of hope,  a glimmer of light in the darkness.

As he turned onto the farm's driveway,  he saw the house,  still standing,  still strong.  He parked his truck,  grabbed his gear,  and walked towards the barn.

The cows were there,  as always,  their eyes following him with a trust born of years.  Duke fed them,  talking softly,  feeling their warmth,  their life,  a stark contrast to the cold,  calculated plan he'd almost carried out.

That night,  Duke slept fitfully,  dreams of his father,  his mother,  the farm,  swirling in his mind.  But there was also a new dream,  one of possibility,  of change,  of a future he had yet to see.

The next day,  Duke made a decision.  He could not save the farm,  not in the way his father had wanted.  But he could keep the legacy alive,  in a new way.  He would sell the land,  just as his father had feared,  but not for the reasons Duke had imagined.  The money would provide him with a new start,  a fresh opportunity to honor the land,  the family,  and his own future.

The process was painful,  filled with goodbyes to the past,  to the dreams that would remain unfulfilled.  But as Duke walked away from the farm for the last time,  he did so with his head held high,  his heart full of hope.

The city,  once a place of fear,  now represented a chance,  a chance to rebuild,  to start anew.  Duke's path was no longer defined by the land that had shaped him.  It was now his to forge,  with his own hands,  his own will.

Years passed,  and Duke became a symbol,  a testament to resilience and renewal.  He found a new passion,  new purpose,  and a new family.  But he never forgot his roots,  the land that had given him everything,  and the lessons he had learned from the drought,  from the echoes of his past,  and from the passage of time itself.

The farmhouse stood empty,  a silent guardian of memories,  a beacon of hope for those who followed.  And Duke,  once a farmer,  now a pioneer,  looked back on his life with gratitude,  knowing that no matter where the road led,  his heart would always be anchored in the fading light of the farm that had been his home.

[Story]: I have a ghost.


In my house. I think.

My husband.

I think.

I'm tapping loudly on my computer. I do everything loudly now. I bang open cabinets, slam drawers, pound my fuzzy slippers heavily on the ground. To let the ghost know I'm here. To warn him of my presence. Because it's when I'm sneaking… that he finds me.

This house aches. I ache - that kind of … rich people ache. A clean, hollow, Hitchcockian ache. A whistling ache. The wind rips right through you. I know because I've been both. A poor person's ache feels damp. Heavy. Waterlogged. The wind can't rip it. Nothing can.

I inherited this house. And ghosts aren't the only things I've inherited with it. Brown widows (me?). Brown recluses (also me). Spindly creepy crawly heat-seeking things, determined to share my life. To take refuge from the doldrums of our island's winter tantrums. I've been alone here for a year and a half, but still, every time I flip on a light switch to reveal a fat centipede skitter under my bed, or a gilt edged silver fish looking up at me from the clawfoot tub - hot terror catches me.

All creatures I somehow never remember seeing while my husband was alive. Sometimes I wonder if the house is really mine, or if it was always theirs. With the ringing absence of my late husband's stewardship, it is changing hands, being returned back to the land. And the original owners are finding their way in through the cracks. Foundations loosening. Spirits and bugs welcome.

Looking at me, you wouldn't think I'm the type to be haunted by the ghost of a husband who can't move on. And yet, I fear, that is exactly what is happening.

It's a little flattering, really. At 38, I've kept up pretty good. Mainly, my hair. It's a little brassy from decades of blonde bottle dye, the ends crispy and straw-like, but I have not yet succumbed to that short haircut women fall victim to at my age. The haircut of a woman disappearing. A certain time of year I sport a rich, golden tan. But a lifetime of beach bumming with no sunscreen has taken its toll. My face dotted with faint patches and lines, settlers upon this land, seizing it and claiming it as their own. I've got the skinny legs of a teenager. Of a sand piper's, nearly invisible, scurrying away from the crash of the shore. But my top half resembles that of a dumpling. Storing all my softness at my center, with heaving breasts like overripe fruit. My thinness radiating out, trying its best to stretch away, to defy the pull of a centrifugal dough ball force. I have small brown eyes. Almond shaped and light, like watery coffee with shiny hazel flecks. Big full lips, and a flat ass. A few tattoos. From over the years. Maybe a few more than I'd like. But, they prove good conversation starters anyway. I'm regular white, but don't always look it, no one knows why. A Portuguese grandad on my mom's side, I've heard? But like most family lore… probably meaningless.

I pad my way down the spiral staircase that dizzyingly dumps me at the door.

"Coming down!" I elongate the syllables like I'm trying them out for the first time.

—

March on the coast is unnerving.

Block Island has abandonment issues.

She shivers and creaks and forces you to love her. Once the tourists and second-homers pack up at the end of summer, she gives her chosen ones sixty days of pure pleasure, reigniting their shaken faith. Devilishly drawing them in, captivating them … until they become captive. Blinded by her piercing beauty, her golden September afternoons, her sweet loganberry harvest, the best of her treasures saved for the most loyal. Her October plenty. Her blazing red leaves and edible purple skies. Her bright salty mornings and crab boil nights. She wraps you in her arms so tight that come November - you can't breathe. You're being - choked. Her thrashing waters, a bride in hysterics. She cries "Why does everyone leave me?" "Why can't they stay when I need them most?" The storm of her petulance tiring even herself out. Then, her loneliness turns punishing. "I love you, don't leave me". "Prove that you love me. Prove you won't ever leave. If you truly love me, take my choppy seas and caustic winds. Take my blistering freeze, my cavernous hallows. Can you take it? My shrouded mourning gown, my grey forever."

So we do. Until summer, when growing fat off the adoration of mere strangers, she turns her sun gaze away from the ones who steadied her in her bleak fit of winter. Bitterly, we blame the trampling tourist - you know the kind, throwing his money around and leaving. But deep down, every New Shoreham resident understands, if we sit still within ourselves, our ire is misplaced. That our woman chose someone else to shine on. We are back in competition with the handsome drifter.

So, March. March on the island is as sapless as it is serpentine. As dull as it is aching. Call it cabin fever. Call it winter blues. Call it anything other than what it is. A desire to leave.

—

My marriage to Jordan was fine. Really! We loved each other in a way that is truly underrated: A love balanced on the scales of "You don't acknowledge my flaws, and I won't acknowledge yours." We supported each other and stayed out of each others way. The sort of love that has fallen out of fashion now. The kind where I didn't work and I was fine with that. The kind where you both get what you asked for, then realize you both asked for the wrong thing, but you stick with it anyway. The kind where we never wanted kids because we never wanted to rouse such strong feelings. Even for each other. We did have a dog named Chester. And we loved him a medium amount. So it's… strange that… now that Jordan's dead… he wants me so bad.

I swipe my keys off the hook and zip my coat. A big puffy one I found in the attic. Forest green with a khaki collar. I smooth balm from the pocket over my chapping lips. I feel like he's watching me. Even now.

"I'm going out" I yell, into the stagnant air.

—

The door chimes as I slink from the pitiless, ashen afternoon into the dark bar. Warm and humming - the belly of the whale. I sidle up and in the mirror, catch myself flipping my hair to one side and over my shoulder with wanton flair.

I had been a waitress all my life. Well, my previous life. My pre-Jordan life. Since I was 14, I worked the Rhode Inn every summer, wearing white t-shirts that read "Rhode Hard and Put Away Wet". That's where we met, actually. He was a city boy. Boston. Invested some capital in a few of our local dives along the coast. Degree in Finance, the whole bit. Did a good job, really. Not overbearing, not trying to "class it up", corporatize us. They were popular little joints, so he wasn't trying to fix what wasn't broke.

"Want some oysters, Kat? Boat just came in." Trish stood comfortably, some rags in hand, her red hair gelled back into one severe ponytail.

"Nah, I'm OK."

"Ky's out back." She says, her back to me.

Her knees crack as she squats down, pulling sharpie-dated quart containers of soupy, red cocktail sauce out of a low boy. I try to sound casual, like I'm not quite sure why she'd be telling me where Ky is.

"Oh. OK."

Ky was my weakness. Is now, and always will be forever, amen. The broad, thick chest of a working man. Sea grey eyes, and the touch of someone whose presence is so crushing he had to learn, the hard way, how to handle the delicate things he loomed over. Hapless and unpolished, but careful. A hearty grin when he'd give it.

I fidget with my wallet while Trish slides me a Sam Adams.

"Put that away!" she scolds.

"Thanks." I smile sheepishly.

I put a coaster over my beer after the first sip and fish a pack of cigarettes out of my pocket.

—

Behind the restaurant, I hover. My plan is to wait for him to say something first. To happen upon me.

"Kat! Heads up!"

It's Tony. My favorite pint-sized maniac, unloading ingredients from the back of a box truck with feverish irregularity. I look in the direction of his voice, and he lobs an industrial bag of sea salt at my head. I dodge it just in time. It puts out my cigarette.

"What the FUCK Tony!" I yelp.

"You'll live!" He responds brightly, as I fumble with my lighter.

"Havin' a drink?" He asks, candy-coated in envy. He slaps one commercial kitchen sized vacuum sealed pork loin over each shoulder and hops off the truck, his knees buckling ever-so-slightly.

I nod, taking a long drag.

"You can have that, by the way. It's expired." His "i's" wide and throaty, an old-school New England accent stuck around his tonsils.

"Whatdoyathink I'm gonna need a five pound bag of expired salt for?"

"Your drive way!" Tony yells forcefully, rolling his eyes.

"Always tryin' ta provide for the helpless widow…" I jab back, with over-measured precision and pitch perfect volume, aimed just-so at the back of the truck. Hoping Ky can hear.

Just then, Ky emerges, hauling clams, headed for the walk-in.

"I could think of something else to do with a helpless widow…" He breathes, brushing my coat with his crooked elbow.

The air between us sharpens.

And my unfortunate first thought is: Jordan.

Dammit. I might need this salt after all.

—

Amid the dregs of winter, having no job and a dead husband, I found I left the house less and less— which meant I rarely saw it from this angle. I pull into the driveway and idle, craning my neck up.

It's impressive. Built in 1888, it's a classic example of the Victorian style of architecture known as Queen Anne. Nantucket blue with white trim and cranberry stained accents. Three sweeping stories embraced by a wrap-around porch with turned posts, decorative brackets, and spindlework.

Its asymmetrical facade gives it the character of a person. Multifaceted, tiresome. Showing some things off with a flourish of Dutch gables—and concealing others, the way we do. Its most prominent features on display like stories we tell over and over at parties. Its second-story balcony almost pouts with disuse, sagging slightly under a proud polygonal turret, dramatically built on a series of bay windows—a final, trumpeting declaration. "I used to be someone, something".

Not sure Jordan's parents were too thrilled when he left the house solely to me. But they retained the Boston assets, washed me out of their Supper Club hair, and I got to stay. Here. At home. The island of my teenaged summers.

And so did Jordan. Apparently.

—

"I'm home!" I bang and crash through the foyer. "It's fucking freezing in here." I say aloud, the door slamming behind me.

It is then that I see it— four french doors helplessly thrashing against their frames in the wind. Cabinets in the kitchen all open. Whisks and muddlers violently askew on the floor. Umbrellas spilled from a shattered standing vase.

Then a side-splitting howl, as an angry gust of sea wind whips through the naked, open channel that is now my house. Suddenly, I kneel to the ground and weep. I give up. Why is he doing this to me?

—

It didn't make sense. One, he didn't die here. In the house. He died in a car accident. A little over a year ago. In Providence, on his way home from a lunch meeting. If people are going to haunt, they're usually going to do it at the *site* of their death. Stuck there. Unwilling to move on, but unable to exist outside a loop, playing out their death over and over, trying to get it right this time. I know because I've done my research. Had a psychic over in November. A local woman with soft white hair piled on her head, an excess of earrings, and virtually non-stop chatter about angels. She refused to step beyond the porch, claiming she felt she wasn't "invited" by the house, until I reminded her *I'm the one* "inviting" her to make that $100/hour she insisted on.

So. She tells me. If your loved one turns into a ghost, a haunting, a spirit caught between planes, it's either because:



1. Their death was untimely
2. Their death was horrifically violent.

OK. Jordan was 49 when he died. So yes, too young. But not exceedingly young. Not "he had his whole life ahead of him" young. I mean, not two generations ago, that was a perfectly reasonable age to forever etch on a tombstone. His car accident, as tragic as it was, wasn't exceptionally horrific either. Just your average death. Pretty symbolic of a lot in Jordan's life.

But *even if* those two criteria were met, the psychic assured me that spirits of the departed are *still* likely to haunt the place they died in.

But he's not haunting a busy stretch of I-95… He's haunting me.

He died in me.

Somehow.

"And one more thing" she said. Stopping me, as her glasses fogged, one foot out the door, her pale eyes growing paler. "It could be unfinished business. That's c." The ABCs of haunting.

Unfinished business. The unfinished business of what exactly? I loved him—I want to make that one thing clear. I did love him. I smile when I think about his jet dark hair, perfect in that boxy, side-parted Republican way. His brooding countenance - the sort of etched severity that promises trouble below. Except with Jordan, there was no darkness. He had no demons. That was just how his face looked.

I miss his big vocabulary, that phone voice he reserved for "business calls", the fake laugh he used on demanding restaurant patrons, or that easy way he fell asleep, every limb draped over mine.

He was never vindictive. Never looking for ways people could hurt him, the way I do. Sure, maybe… maybe we'd've been better off as friends, but we also *wanted* the same things: Comfort. This beach. Cold beer. This house. Using Chester-the-unruly-dog as an alibi to never visit his parents or sister. A medium sized boat.

He was never this passionate in life. He wasn't even particularly stubborn. Unfinished business felt so uncharacteristically romantic by comparison. My throat itches as I wonder if the unfinished business we had was in never loving each other recklessly. Totally. Always skating through life unannounced. Never asking ourselves "Isn't it supposed to be more beautiful than this?"

Now, I sweep up the broken vase and put the kitchen back together. It's the best I can do."

The house settled down,  its windows still,  the wind outside softening into a more reasonable,  melancholic sigh.  I stood in the center of the kitchen,  wiping my hands on my jeans,  and looked around.  The scene of chaos had been restored to order,  but the feeling of unease lingered.  I couldn't shake the sensation that I was being watched.

 As I turned off the kitchen lights and made my way up the spiral staircase,  my mind was a whirlwind of thoughts.  The psychic's words,  the unfinished business,  the fact that Jordan's spirit had chosen to haunt me and not the place of his death—it was all too much to ponder at once.

 Back in my room,  I lay on the bed,  staring at the ceiling,  trying to piece it all together.  It was then that I heard it—a soft,  familiar sound.  I sat up,  listening intently,  my heart pounding.  It was a melody,  a song Jordan used to hum when he was deep in thought or working on a particularly challenging problem.  I had heard it countless times,  but never like this.  It seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere,  floating in the air around me.

 I slowly got up and followed the sound,  which led me to the piano in the living room.  Jordan had always been a talented musician;  his parents were concert pianists,  and he had learned from the best.  But he rarely played for me;  it was one of the many things about him that I hadn't known how to ask for.

 As I approached the piano,  I realized the song was playing by itself.  The keys were moving,  and the music that filled the room was his.  Tears welled up in my eyes as I watched,  a mixture of fear and longing.  I wanted to believe this was a sign,  a message from Jordan,  but part of me was terrified it was a trick,  a manipulation.

 "Jordan? " I whispered,  hoping to hear his voice,  any indication of his presence.  But there was only silence,  save for the music.

 I sat down and began to play,  trying to replicate the melody.  As my fingers moved across the keys,  I felt a surge of emotion,  a connection to Jordan that I hadn't felt since his death.  It was as if,  through the music,  we were speaking again,  communicating in a way we never had before.

 The song ended,  and I sat there,  breathing heavily.  I knew what I had to do.  I had to face the fact that Jordan's spirit was with me for a reason,  and it was time to address it.  I had to confront the unfinished business between us.

 Over the next few weeks,  I began to explore my feelings,  both about Jordan and about myself.  I had always been content with our quiet,  stable life,  but now I saw it for what it was—a lack of passion,  a settling.  I had never asked for more from Jordan,  and he had never offered it.  But now,  with his spirit lingering,  I felt a sense of urgency.  I wanted more for us,  even if it was too late for us in this life.

 I started going to the bar more often,  not just to see Ky or Tony,  but to engage in conversations,  to live a little.  I even took up photography,  capturing the beauty of the island,  the moments of joy and pain that people experienced.  It was a way of connecting with others,  of finding passion in my own life.

 And then,  one evening,  as I was walking home from the bar,  I saw something out of the corner of my eye—a figure standing at the edge of the sea,  looking out at the water.  It was Jordan,  or at least,  his spirit.  He was dressed in his favorite sweater,  the one I had always loved to see him in.  He turned to look at me,  and it was as if he was saying goodbye.

 "I'm letting go, " I whispered,  knowing he could hear me.  "I'm letting go,  Jordan. "

 He nodded,  then turned back to the sea,  the wind picking up around him until he was no more,  dissolving into the night.

 I stood there for a long time,  letting the cold air wash over me.  I realized that the unfinished business between us wasn't about what we hadn't done;  it was about what I had learned to do without him.  I had learned to live,  to find passion,  to let go.

 As I walked back to the house,  I felt lighter,  like a weight had been lifted from my shoulders.  I knew I would always miss Jordan,  but I no longer felt haunted by him.  I had found a way to honor our relationship,  to move forward while holding onto the memories.

 The house was quiet when I entered,  the wind having died down completely.  I looked around,  taking in the familiar sights,  feeling a sense of peace for the first time in a long while.  I knew the journey wasn't over;  there were still challenges ahead,  but I felt ready to face them.

 With a newfound sense of purpose,  I began to plan my next steps.  I wanted to continue exploring my passions,  to make a life for myself that was truly my own.  The house,  with all its quirks and ghosts,  would be my home,  a place of memories and growth.  And though Jordan was no longer with me in the physical world,  I knew his spirit would always be a part of this place,  a reminder of the love we shared and the lessons we learned together.

 As I settled into bed that night,  I felt a deep sense of gratitude.  For the life I had with Jordan,  for the life that lay ahead,  and for the journey that had brought me to this moment.  I closed my eyes,  knowing that no matter what the future held,  I was ready to face it with an open heart and a spirit unburdened by the past.

You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: It had been decided that the machine must go. I didn"t find myself agreeing with Major Milic very much these days. His methods were harsh, brutal and he had become a fanatic. I"d call him more of a terrorist than a freedom fighter. But he was right, the machine had to go. I didn"t have any confidence we could do it, however.


The resistance had changed in the last couple years. The Emperor"s personal secret project was brought online. Though it was round, it wasn"t like it the "Death Star." This Empire was real, and it made smarter decisions. It spent its time and money on a brain. CyCLOPS- Cybernetic, Control, Law-enforcement, and Online Policing System- changed the rules of human nature more and more every day. It make it possible for a few people to effectively watch the entire human populace at once. It watched, it learned, it analyzed, it predicted, and it remembered with perfect clarity all at a single time.

I had been surprised at first when Major Milic rescued me from my prison, but not when I figured out what he planned to do. He needed me for two reasons. One- I could fly helicopters, the old ones without autopilot. Two- I knew where CyCLOPS was. And I suppose a third reason too; I would never turn him into the Imperial Union.

I agreed to help, not that I had a lot of choice when everything I knew was lost and there was a gun in my face. I left the prison behind, but all the while knowing I would die with them instead.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

CyCLOPS is not easy to get near. It was secret to begin with, but they knew better than to rely on that alone. Through torture, Major Milic"s loyal team discovered a lot information about the facility. Though most work with it is done remotely, it has over 500 that work directly with the machine on-site. These are mostly fat technicians and overpaid civilians, not that Milic recognized civilians anymore. They wouldn"t put up much of a fight when push came to shove.

The security came from a reinforced, mixed-guard company made up of Sentinels and Assault Forces. One company of three platoons. Each platoon covered a 12-hour shift. One was on days, one on nights, one on recovery cycle at all times. They had six guard towers with heavy machine guns on the walled perimeter. The walls were made of carbonized concrete, the gate was heavy metal and automatic, and there was electrified razor wire across the top. Four roving patrols covered the exterior of the facility, rejecting any trespassers onto the "Navajo Sanctuary Reservation." At least one large armored vehicle was ready at all times for a quick reaction force. The rest of the on-shift platoon patrolled the inside of the compound and checked key points.

If at any point the guards caught wind of our approach and intentions, the other platoons would be woken and activated as reserves. An entire company of heavily armed and armored Sentinels would be vastly too much to deal with, and we"d be slaughtered. We had to 1- approach undetected, 2- blind the guard towers so they could not shoot down our helicopters, 3- secure the barracks and take the reserves hostage before they could get to their arms room, 4- deal with the existing guards in the compound, 5- lock the gate to prevent the roving patrols from returning with more firepower, 6- break into and make our way into the facility, and at last, 7- blow CyCLOPS to high hell. None of the major processor banks can survive. No one knows the extent of its capabilities for certain, besides the Emperor and his chosen team, but it may likely begin to back up its data to external servers outside of the facility. The more we can destroy, the more we"ve set back the Empire, and the more time we've bought for a larger resistance to mobilize.

They are dependent on the machine now. They will be weaker than they were before it"s installation. But first, we had to get there. And I had a bad feeling. So many things could go wrong.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I listened as intently as I could to Milic"s briefing. He"d thought of everything. Even from his little bunker hidden away from the world, he"d managed to gather a lot of intelligence. From his position at the top of the map, he could point out every section of the base, where we would land, where the satellite communications were, where the barracks and arms rooms were, where we would enter the facility, and more. I wasn"t sure how he knew all of this. I think I didn"t want to know.

"Sam, are you fuckin" paying attention!?" His eyes seemed to glow from the light reflected off the map in the otherwise dark bunker.

"What? Yes. I know where to land." Truthfully I"d never been the same since that prison. I couldn"t focus on anything too long.

"But after that?"

"What... what am I doing after that? That wasn"t... I didn"t agree to-"

"I don"t give a shit. You"re with me. I"m not letting you out of my sight."

"Who"s going to stay with the helicopter?"

"Jacob will keep it running." He pointed to Powell, next to me. Anyone who knew him called him Powell. Only people who pretended to know him called him Jake or Jacob. They"d had a long history, but that told me how close they weren"t. Powell"s eyes locked with mine for a moment then looked away. He was a hostage here, too. He was the man that taught me to fly. He was old now. So was I.

"I"m not shooting anyone."

"That"s fine. You"ll help carry explosives. You"ve got no problem blowing this thing up. That"s what we agreed on, right?"

"Okay... right. I"m with you."

"You"re attached to my hip. You go where I fuckin" tell you and nowhere else. Is that understood?"

"I"m with you." I growled.

"3rd squad, alpha-team"s goals are the communications array..." he continued. But again, I already wasn"t listening. A faint whining grew in my ears, and I faded out into one of my blackout spells. After coming all this way, and everything I"ve worked for- everything I did to fight the Empire- it was probably Milic that was going to kill me.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

During pre-flight checks with Powell, we talked a little bit. It was nice. I climbed up on top of the back of the bird to give the yoke a good look.

"This piece of shit is not gonna fly." I interjected, looked at the rust near the blade hub.

"It"ll fly. I flew it yesterday."

"The rotors are going to fall off before we get there."

"No... but we"re in for a bumpy ride. She definitely handles like a... heh heh, Sammy, you remember that old two-seater we flew up to that Appalachian relay station?"

"Oh dear god, we almost died. On three separate occasions." I grinned.

"We"ve been through tougher spots." Powell grinned too and climbed up the other side. His entire bald head wrinkled when he smiled.

"Yeah... but we were younger men. And the Empire didn"t rule the world yet."

"Nothing lasts forever. Not youth, and not this crummy empire. They all fall down eventually. We"re just giving it a good shove."

"You really think we"re going to win?" my grin faded. That old feeling returned.

"I think so. Major Milic"s got his plan down tight. He"s resourced everything he needs. We have our opening. You don"t think we can?"

The yoke, despite several conditions I would normally reject, appeared okay. The blades were in surprisingly good condition. It would fly all the way to the scene of the crash. "I don"t think so."

"You need to give the guy more credit. I know you don"t agree with his methods, but he"s a warrior. This is what he was built for. You have that prison mindset still. The walls are all closed in around you."

"Oh I don"t think it"s the prison that got to me," I looked out into the setting sun of the evening. The scenery from up here was incredible.

"Is this about Lindsey?"

"No. Lindsey"s gone. This is about us. Now. Though I admit, it"s hard to forget her face with a bullet in it. I"m glad she"s not here to see this. This is going to be... a mess."

Powell reached up and grabbed my hand and held it in both of his. "You"ve gotta have a little faith in this team. They know what they"re doing."

"I know. But this team never met the Emperor. I"ve met him, and... No one on earth knows what they"re doing compared to him. He sees everything coming."

"Sam, you have to believe we can win."

"I know... there"s a chance we can win. But we need to be ready. If it"s not a trap now, it will be by the time we get there." The sun slipped from view, and we were left standing in the dark."

As the night drew in, the air grew heavy with the anticipation of what was to come. The resistance team, a ragtag band of rebels bonded only by their hatred for the Empire and their resolve to dismantle CyCLOPS, prepared for what might be their last stand. The helicopter, though old and creaky, hummed to life under Powell's skilled hands. The old veteran, with his weathered face and eyes that had seen too much, took one last look around the makeshift base before climbing into the cockpit.

"Remember," he said, his voice a mixture of resignation and determination, "we're not just fighting for the Empire's downfall. We're fighting for our future. For our freedom. For the right to live as human beings, not as cogs in the machine."

Sam nodded, his mind a whirlwind of thoughts and fears. The image of Lindsey, his comrade turned traitor, dying in his arms flashed through his mind. The pain of losing her, coupled with the weight of what they were about to attempt, threatened to overtake him. But then he remembered the faces of those who had stood by him, the shared moments of hope and despair. He couldn't let them down.

As they lifted off, the city below them a patchwork of light and shadow, Sam couldn't help but feel the gravity of their situation. The plan, meticulously crafted by Milic, was ambitious, to say the least. They would have to be as silent as the night itself to avoid detection by the security apparatus of the Empire. The thought of the Sentinels and Assault Forces lying in wait for them was enough to send shivers down their spines.

The journey was uneventful, save for the occasional distant burst of gunfire. They were not the only rebels on the night. The Empire's grip was loosening, and cracks were starting to show. Sam couldn't help but wonder if this was the beginning of the end for the Emperor and his regime.

They approached the compound with caution, the helicopter's rotors whirring ominously in the still night air. The perimeter was exactly as Milic had described, a fortress in the middle of nowhere designed to keep out everything and everyone. But they had a plan, and they had the element of surprise.

The first part of the plan went off without a hitch. They landed undetected, and Powell and Sam quickly disembarked, explosives in hand, ready to breach the first line of defense. The remaining members of the team fanned out, each with their own objectives. The silence was deafening, a testament to the professionalism of the Empire's guards and the meticulous planning of the resistance.

As they approached the barracks, Sam couldn't shake the feeling that they were being watched. The Empire was always watching, and the thought that CyCLOPS might already be aware of their presence filled him with dread. But there was no turning back now.

The explosion at the gate was their signal. The roaring flames acted as a beacon, drawing the guard's attention away from the barracks. Powell and Sam, with their cover blown, burst through the door, their guns blazing. They were met with confusion and chaos, the guards' initial shock giving them the upper hand.

The operation moved with a speed and precision that surprised even Sam. The reserves were taken captive without a fight, and the existing guards were either neutralized or fled in the face of overwhelming force. The compound was theirs, but the real battle was yet to come.

Breaching the facility was another matter entirely. The walls were reinforced, the doors impenetrable. But Milic had foreseen this, and they were equipped with enough explosives to level the compound. With each detonation, the team moved deeper into the heart of the machine, the weight of their mission pressing down on them.

As they reached the main server room, the realization of what they were about to do hit them. This was it. The moment that could change the course of history. Sam took a deep breath, his fingers trembling as he placed the final charges. The room was filled with the blinking lights of billions of bits of data, the essence of the Empire's power.

"Go," Milic commanded, his voice steady and authoritative.

Powell and Sam retreated to a safe distance, the silence of the facility around them oppressive. The countdown seemed to stretch on forever, the seconds ticking away. Then, in an instant, the world erupted into chaos. The explosion was deafening, the shockwave throwing them to the ground. When the dust cleared, the server room was a smoldering ruin, the machine that had held the Empire together reduced to nothing but rubble.

The team emerged from the compound, the dawn's light casting long shadows on their weary faces. They had done it. They had taken down CyCLOPS. But the victory was bittersweet. The Empire would not go down without a fight, and the resistance had lost many good men and women in the process.

As they made their escape, Sam couldn't help but wonder what the future held. The Empire was weakened, but the road to freedom was long and fraught with danger. He knew that they had only won one battle, not the war. But for now, they had hope. And that, Sam realized, was something worth fighting for.

The helicopter lifted off once more, the horizon painted with the colors of dawn. The city below was a battlefield, but somewhere out there, the seeds of rebellion were being sown. The resistance had taken a stand, and no matter what happened next, they would never be the same. The fight for freedom was far from over, but they had shown that even the mightiest could fall. And in the end, that was all they could ask for.

[Story]: My name is Kristin Renee Saunders, and my life has become crazy in a big fucking way. And the shit part is I can't even tell anyone about it. Forget talking to my therapist, she'd have me locked up and the key thrown away if I attempted to unload any of my problems and experiences. After all, who would believe anyone who said they were involved in a murderous power-grab between witches, vampires, werewolves and other supernatural races?


Not one damn person, that's who.

But if I don't get this off my chest, I might lock me up and throw away the key. If only not to get killed by something that doesn't have a box next to it on a coroner's report.

It all started a few months back, while I was waiting tables at the Whistle Stop. The Whistle is a small little restaurant in Glendale, Kentucky that serves up the best southern dishes and desserts in the area. Folks travel everywhere from Louisville to out of state, and I've even served folks from as far away as Cali and Alaska. We have many regulars, but it's not uncommon to see strange folks here, even if Glendale is literally a one-stop-sign kinda place.

The two women at table ten made me strangely uneasy from the beginning, requesting a table as far away from any of the others as possible. When Hailey, the hostess, sat them at table ten , I felt an inside groan. Table ten- the haunted table. Not that anyone had actually seen a ghost, but unexplainable things always seem to happen there. Drinks will unexplainably topple over or dishes will slip out of even the most experienced servers' hands. No matter who is sitting at table ten, you just know something is going to happen.

I smiled my most winning smile at the two ladies. One of the women looked to be in her mid-thirties, with dark hair and eyes. She was well-dressed in a pair of slacks with a form-fitting shirt that made it clear she was in excellent shape, and a jacket that matched her sensibly-low heels. In short, she was dressed like Beckett in an episode of Castle, or any other female cop in a prime-time, murder-porn TV show.

The other looked to be in her mid-twenties, with long, wild sandy blonde hair that fell in waves past her shoulders. It looked like it had not been brushed in several days. She was wearing faded jeans and sneakers, and a faded black Realtree sweatshirt with cammo lettering.

In short, these women could not have appeared less likely to be dining together. But whatever. I'm not here to ask questions, right?

The well-dressed woman said she had eaten earlier and simply ordered water with a slight English accent. The younger woman ordered country-style steak, two orders of fried chicken, and two slices of Kentucky pie. I wondered how someone could possibly put away that much food , but hey… big bill, big tip. Who am I to question? Maybe she had a tapeworm.

I had just finished scrubbing the tea urns after promising my manager Tess that I would lock up. The women were the last two people other than myself in the building and I had already cleared the dishes and was waiting for them to pay and leave. I finished closing work in the kitchen and headed out the back door that lead to the dining area and around to the front of the building to check that the lights were off. I was about to round the corner into their section when I first caught wind of their conversation . I should have just delivered the bill and minded my own fucking business. But I've never been good at being sensible. I slipped silently into the next dining room area to listen as pieces of their conversation floated towards me.

"….. Can't kill him, he holds too much power…"

"Even the witches would not dare ."

"….Can't control the pack for much longer."

"Vampires have not had a council outside what the Vatican controls in centuries,"

What the fuck? Murder? Witches? Vampires in the Vatican?

Actually having been raised Catholic, that last part I could believe.

I was still hiding in the next dining room when they went silent. Could they hear me? Did they know I was back there? I crawled my way to the doorway that connected the two dining room, hoping to covertly peek around the corner. I prayed the damn ancient saloon-style double doors wouldn't squeak too much when I opened them. Then again, I wasn't exactly able crawl all that silently, either. The building is over 120 years old and has all the original flooring. It groans and squeaks with just about every movement. I cursed all the times I chose tacos over going to the gym as I gingerly tried to make my way to the doors.

When I got there, I decided not to risk trying to open the doors. Instead, I stuck my head under them only far enough to look under the booths to double check that the two ladies were still there. I briefly praised my own foresight in having already throughly swept and mopped the floor. Maybe Grandpa's half-eaten biscuits and gravy wouldn't end up in my hair.

Table ten was empty.

I was so shocked I went to stand up so quickly I forgot I was under the doors, and cracked my head. I rubbed the rising knot on my scalp and looked around, but there was no sign of the two women. I rushed around the restaurant seeing if maybe they had gone to use the restroom before paying their bill. No dice. I even checked the kitchen. Nothing.

I heaved a sigh. Great. Now not only am I the last one here, my last table was two crazy ladies who dined and dashed on me. Assholes.

I finished my last duties and stepped out the back door into the cool autumn evening. We were already busy when I arrived at work earlier, so I had to park clear down Railroad Avenue , and I had a fairly long walk in the dark ahead of me. The streetlights had gone out a while back but Glendale prides itself on being a "community" rather than an actual town. The result was nobody had gotten around to fixing the lights. The median age of the residents being somewhere between 75 and death, everyone was well inside and likely already asleep by the time dark fell. Fixing the streetlights wasn't on anyone's priority list.

I walked past the antique mall and shuddered at the eerie sight of porcelain dolls staring at me in the darkened window display. As I walked down Railroad the houses stopped and there was nothing but cornfield on either side of the little road. I always hate walking by myself simply because it always feels as if someone, something is out there. This night was no different and I tried to walk faster but I could not shake the feeling that I was being watched. Stalked.

When I finally reached my car my hands were clammy and shaking as I dug around my purse for my key fob. I heaved a sigh of relief when my hand found the fob, and went to pull it out when a black blur whizzed beside me.

Before I could blink, I was on my back in a small grassy patch in front of the cornfield, staring into the eyes of the English-accented well-dressed woman. I gasped for breath, the force of her take-down having knocked the wind out of me. I stared into her eyes, continuing to gasp for breath and not piss myself. Her eyes seemed different. Feral. They caught and reflected the moonlight the way animals' eyes do. She bared her teeth at me, revealing canine teeth that were… well, canine-like. It was like staring into the face of someone who had just stepped away from filming a scene for True Blood. I mentally counted down the weeks until Halloween. It seemed far too early to be attending a Halloween costume party.

It sounded like someone else's voice as I gasped out "wha..wha..what do you want?!"

I had hoped to sound defiant. Fearless. Instead, I sounded like an asthmatic mouse with an anxiety disorder. Fabulous.

"What did you hear?" Her voice sounded like a growl.

"Huh? N-n-nothing!" I squeaked.

"Bollocks. I can smell the lies on you. Now is not the time to bullshit. I have other ways of getting the truth from you." Shit. I'm gonna die.

The younger woman's face suddenly loomed over me. She spoke with a thick southern accent, but it wasn't local. "Just kill her and let's go before one of these blue hairs decides to talk a late-night stroll. We have to get going. This little bitch isn't going to fuck up us finding my father or talk shit to the wrong people. She's a loose end. Get rid of her."

I started to scream, hoping one of "those blue hairs" would actually be on a stroll, but the well-dressed woman quickly put her hand over my mouth. She looked up at the younger woman and sneered. "Bloodshed isn't necessary here. This one might be useful. If nothing else, she might know something." She looked down at me. " I suggest you stay quiet. I may be reasonable but my associate here would rip your throat out with her teeth and not think twice. She's rather rash, that one. So be a good girl, hmmm? Now, look at me."

I squeezed my eyes shut. I didn't want to look into those strange, feral eyes. She shook me hard.

"Look at me or I swear, they'll never find what's left of you. Genevieve? Perhaps you might emphasize my point? Let's let our little waitress know this is no idle threat."

My eyes were still glued shut when I heard what sounded like the growl of a very large animal. It was deeper and more menacing than any animal I had ever encountered. At the sound of it my eyes snapped open. The well-dressed woman smiled, revealing those horribly pointed teeth.

"Very good. Now, look at me.There's a good girl."

I stared into those fearsome, strange eyes and they seemed to start to glow. I felt myself become strangely calm. The glow of her eyes seemed to intensify, and I felt my body becoming heavy. I felt myself falling…falling. I was falling into blackness when I heard her faintly say "Good. Now we are going go for a bit of a ride….."

The world went black."

You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: No one I"ve come across in my travels know as to how the curse our world has been given was triggered. What I do know is that we are born with this sickness. This sickness is onset with prolonged sleep. Slowly but consistently it eats away at the mind of the individual leading to an ultimate state of insanity. The result is a mindless, caricature of a former life.


The sickness only occurs with humans, at the very least I"ve never seen an animal like them. They show no interest in animal life and occupy their time with the chaotic desire to kill and consume humans. They are especially effective at this. It must have been a lifetime ago since I had the pleasure of conversation with another.

Truth be told, it was a lifetime away.

I was imprisoned at the Fort Briggs; at least this was what the guard told me. I don"t remember what caused me to be imprisoned or anything beforehand-not sure why. In any event I awoke to a soldier looming over me. The surprise almost caused me to swiftly get to an upright position to greet my company but something in his eyes sent a chill to my heart as if the spear he was also carrying had already impaled my heart. But no, he only sat there resting against the cell, looking not so much at me as in me. It was like my soul was stripped naked and studied, his sunken glare penetrating its very depth.

"Well you"re not one of them, yet anyway. I"m no murderer but perhaps a fool. I couldn"t bring it upon myself to pierce your heart as you slept. I"ve seen the signs though. The cold sweats, the fear, and then nothing. Or at least for a few moments; they finally awake and it"s done. They just start killing and..."

His voice trailed off as he dropped his head. At this point I was upright but I hadn"t made any sudden movements. I have never met a distraught man but this seems like the situation.

But as if possessed he jumped up and whispered,

"They eat us! I-I"ve seen it!"

The dread and repulsion present in his voice was now gone and he returned to his initial position.

"We all knew that sleep causes it, and we fought it off for as long as we could. At last, not all of us had the same resolve. It was a recruit, a young lad who"ve never seen a battle or felt a woman"s warmth. He thought it a good notion to rest his eyes while on guard duty. When they found him, he attacked one of us in the most vicious manner I have ever seen. To think a boy could rip a grown man"s throat asunder! They were able to hack his head off but it wasn"t long before more and more of us started to drop. It"s when you go without sleep that you truly realize how precious the comfort of it is. And so, I"m all that"s left. My brothers-in-arms have all given in. Out of fear of them I protected myself in this cell, only to discover you. "

Afterwards he became quiet, as if he had been waiting endlessly to have someone to speak to. Assuming he was waiting for my retort to this I probed him on my location and such details.

"This is Fort Briggs; you are rather deep in the northern region of Iscariot. I couldn"t tell you why you are here but you have surely been blessed by Tali. There is no one left out there, just them."

Iscariot is the "land of blood" as it"s known. It has conquered several nations; it was thought that the Gods themselves had chosen for Iscariot to rule over all. Fort Briggs is a colossal structure that was created by the now vanished Titans. It occupies a small fissure between two steep highlands, making it the only plausible way to enter Iscariot land from the north. He referred to the Goddess Tali, which is an interesting note as Tali is not worshipped in Iscariot but in Ishla; a country mostly comprised of desert and chasms.

I was so occupied in my thoughts that I didn"t notice the sound of something approaching. The soldier was more alert and gestured for me to remain still and silent. The sound of iron boots grew steadily louder and louder as if it was ensnaring us, trapping us. And as gradually as it appeared, the steps began to drift off-but never did it go away. I never saw anyone but I did notice the soldier. It was if Death itself had gently brushed pass him, taking both his skin color and calm demeanor. I questioned the fear stricken man about what it was.

"Them."

It was clear that he was on the verge of insanity. I wouldn"t blame the poor soul. If he has indeed gone some stretched period without sleep then his state of mind has surely been warped. Seeing this it created an instinctive fear in me. I did not intend to wait in this cell for starvation or madness to overtake me. I made my way towards the cell door, but in a sudden moment the soldier had pointed his spear at me. Those cold, merciless eyes had returned but now with a glint of murderous intent.

"I empathize with you. I too have pondered the prospect of escape from this cell, to fight my way out of the Fort and so on and so forth. No one desires to experience the humility of being a caged animal but this is how it is. To leave this cell, this haven, would result only in a gruesome death."

This man has truly given in to fear and has lost hope of escaping our hell. Not deterred I made my intentions clear to him of me finding my own way out, with or without him.

"You will forgive me then. I have known you for a few moments but in those you have made me think you a sensible person. However, I won"t allow you to potentially jeopardize me! If they find you, then they"ll find me and I intend to go on with the rest of my days.

I"m sorry friend."

Before I had time to respond the soldier lunged his spear towards me. Perhaps Tali is watching after me as the spear struck just under my right arm and collided with the stone wall. The resulting jolt caused the soldier to drop the spear at which I tackled him. I had never been in a situation like this, where I had to fight for my life. We both desperately grasped for each other"s neck while rolling to and fro. I saw the veins rise in his face and his eyes bulge and turn bloodshot. I felt the heat of his skin against mine and the throbbing of his pulse.

I was going to die.

The soldier had obviously been trained to kill and was quite stronger than me and I gradually loosened my grip until he was on top of me and was I was near done for. It was during this I noticed his spear just within reach. With a stretch for life I snatched the weapon and struck him across the face. He stumbled over and grasped his bleeding ear. Not waiting for him to recover I attacked. It wasn"t so much intentional as my body just knew what it had to do. His iron armor covered most of his body so I gouged his face over and over. The squishy noise of each strike felt dark yet consoling and I continued. Blood and other stuff peppered over my face, while his was a red unidentifiable mass-and yet I continued.

Eventually I regained my composure and disgusted at myself I dropped the spear and sat against the opposing wall. It is one thing to hear about people being killed and dying but this was up close and personal. It was a rush at first but now a sober cold sensation remained. I forced myself not to think about what had just transpired. I needed to escape. After searching his body, I did not find a key to the padlock. A few hours went by as I tried to formulate another plan. It was during this I noticed the sound of water running. It grew louder near the rear wall, and upon closer inspection I noticed the water was running from beneath the stone floor. It was cracked in several sections and the thought of breaking open a hole could be possible with the spear. So I enveloped myself in this endeavor, quietly but slowly as not to draw the attention of whatever they are.

Over the course of what was likely several hours I was able to create a big enough hole to at the very least see what lied beneath. It seemed like a sewer of some sort but it was an escape. With the hole open, I only had to chip away at the sides and rather rapidly in contrast to my initial progress it grew to I was able to squeeze through. However the thought occurred to me that I may have to fight my way out and if so I could make better use of the corpse"s armor than he did. It wasn"t as heavy as I thought it would be but the added size required I expand the hole more.

I found myself now in a dark sewer like burrow. It was too dark to see what I was stepping in but I tried not to think about it nonetheless. Treading the thick liquid in full armor was not pleasant. Mounted in a corner was a torch which I carried with me as I cautiously made my way through the ever-curving tunnel. I had to hold the spear in one hand and its weight became more noticeable. Its tip was also twisted and rounded from it being used to break through the floor.

Eventually I came across a metal ladder to a manhole. Holding the torch in one hand, the spear in my mouth I climbed the ladder but found that the manhole was exceedingly heavy. Again, the spear was used to break it lose and I was able to crack it open and subsequently open to reveal a grey sky. I then remembered the northern region of Iscariot is consistently cold, with snow falling year-round.







Then I saw them."
